medical_history.chief_complaint: Watery, urine-like diarrhea starting on the 3rd day of life.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The symptoms began on the 3rd day of life with watery diarrhea, which persisted throughout his life, with stool volume exceeding 250 ml/kg per day and frequency of defecation between 2-18 times daily. By 1 month, he weighed 2700 grams and continued to receive only TPN. He developed abdominal distension and pseudo obstructions by 2 months. Throughout his life, he experienced dehydration, metabolic acidosis, and multiple complications. Cholestasis occurred but regressed by 5 months of age.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Complications included catheter-related sepsis, iron deficiency anemia, catheter-related thrombosis, vitamin D deficiency, hepatosteatosis, and non-selective proteinuria. He never initiated oral feeding and was dependent on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Delayed psychomotor development was noted.
